text:
Faith Mason was left with 40 broken bones after she was horrifically abused by her biological aprents (Picture: 12 News) A baby who was horrifically abused by her biological parents and was left with more than 40 broken bones has officially been adopted by a loving new family. 
Mum who hid baby son’s body for 11 years is jailed Baby Faith Mason was found to have injuries so severe, authorities had compared it to falling from a two-storey building, after she was taken to A&E by her mother, Christine Johnson, in 2013.
Doctors found she had suffered at least 40 broken bones and fractures, including two broken arms, two broken legs, a broken neck and dislocated shoulder.
Three years on, Faith has now been officially adopted by a loving new family (Picture: 12News) Faith’s case was considered the ‘worst ever’ that medics had seen (Picture: 12News) They also said many of the one-month-old’s fractures were about three weeks old at the time she was examined.
Johnson was subsequently jailed for 65 years in 2015 for abusing Faith while her dad Darrell Mason was jailed for 25 years in 2016 for failing to stop the abuse.

Faith’s mother, Christine Johnson, was jailed for 65 years in 2015 (Picture: 12news) Faith’s dad Darrell Mason was jailed for 25 years in 2016 for failing to stop the abuse. (Picture: Jefferson Co. Sheriff’s Office) Medics on duty when Faith was brought in called the abuse the worst case they had ever seen, the Port Arthur News reported.
During a court hearing last year, prosecutors said Faith was still being fed through a feeding tube and her left arm had still not healed properly since the abuse was uncovered.
Faith was officially adopted by her new family on March 10. (Picture: Texas DFPS) MORE: Mum carrying terminally ill baby to full term explains decision in touching video 
Now three years on, Faith is still recovering from her horrific abuse injuries but has got a permanent home after she was officially adopted by her new family on March 10.
The little girl had been living with her adoptive parents and three teenage siblings for the past six months, according to the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services.
